chapter.title: Writing NixOS Documentation
chapter.para: As NixOS grows, so too does the need for a catalogue and explanation of its extensive functionality. Collecting pertinent information from disparate sources and presenting it in an accessible style would be a worthy contribution to the project.
The DocBook sources of the are in the nixos/doc/manual subdirectory of the Nixpkgs repository.

section.title: Writing for the Manual
section.para: To get started, open a Nix shell in your local checkout of Nixpkgs.
Create the automatically generated NixOS Options documentation files with docs-generate.

To validate your edits, run docs-validate. Validation uses jing to produce higher quality error messages. If you see a validation error inside a Nix build, try using docs-validate inside the Nix shell for debugging.
If docs-validate is not producing an error message which makes sense, try running docs-debug which will individually validate files to try and isolate the source of your problem:
Before committing your changes, make sure to format the documentation with docs-format:
section.screen: [nix-shell:nixos/doc/manual]$ docs-format [nix-shell:nixos/doc/manual]$ git status On branch docs/writing-improvements Changes not staged for commit: modified: development/writing-documentation.xml
section.para: Finally, build the documentation inside the Nix shell with docs-build:

section.title: Editing DocBook XML
section.para: For general information on how to write in DocBook, see DocBook 5: The Definitive Guide.
Emacs nXML Mode is very helpful for editing DocBook XML because it validates the document as you write, and precisely locates errors. To use it, see .

Pandoc can generate DocBook XML from a multitude of formats, which makes a good starting point.
Pandoc invocation to convert GitHub-Flavoured MarkDown to DocBook 5 XML pandoc -f markdown_github -t docbook5 docs.md -o my-section.md
Pandoc can also quickly convert a single section.xml to HTML, which is helpful when drafting.
Sometimes writing valid DocBook is simply too difficult. In this case, submit your documentation updates in a GitHub Issue and someone will handle the conversion to XML for you.

section.title: Creating a Topic
section.para: You can use an existing topic as a basis for the new topic or create a topic from scratch.

Keep the following guidelines in mind when you create and add a topic:
The NixOS book element is in nixos/doc/manual/manual.xml. It includes several parts which are in subdirectories.
Store the topic file in the same directory as the part to which it belongs. If your topic is about configuring a NixOS module, then the XML file can be stored alongside the module definition nix file.
If you include multiple words in the file name, separate the words with a dash. For example: ipv6-config.xml.
Make sure that the xml:id value is unique. You can use abbreviations if the ID is too long. For example: nixos-config.
Determine whether your topic is a chapter or a section. If you are unsure, open an existing topic file and check whether the main element is chapter or section.

section.title: Adding a Topic to the Book
section.para: Open the parent XML file and add an xi:include element to the list of chapters with the file name of the topic that you created. If you created a section, you add the file to the chapter file. If you created a chapter, you add the file to the part file.
If the topic is about configuring a NixOS module, it can be automatically included in the manual by using the meta.doc attribute. See for an explanation.
